So far, this year has sucked, but, there is a lesson in everything depending on how you look at it.

It seems as if Shorts attack low priced stocks, as they know that’s where most Retail Investors play (the game is transfer money from the amateurs to the professionals).  These SPACs where a goldmine for the Shorts.

Note to self:  Stay the F away from low priced stocks, or, be mentally prepared to hold for at least 3 years.

Thankfully, I’m not in all of these, and for the two that I am, my cost basis isn’t that much higher than the current price, and my LT Thesis hasn’t changed.

I like this space.

For context and perspective, as we’re all pretty frustrated with the price action lately.

The only way to beat the street is, during times like these, take advantage of the low cost basis due to ST attacks, and start building a portfolio of stocks that will be the dominant players in their field, 3-5yrs from now.

The biggest advantage that the street has, aside from the amount of money controlled by funds used to manipulate pricing in the ST, is that most retail trades; I.e. holdings are usually less than 1yr (actually a high % is 3 months or less).

Remove the 1yr variable, and we swing the advantage somewhat back in our favor.  Don’t play by their rules.

Do we think that $BODY $FUBO $SOFI $AMRS $PRCH will be at these prices 3-5yrs from now?  I don’t; so this down cycle is the perfect time to build out a portfolio that will reap huge rewards 3yr+ down the road.

Is it painful to watch and remain patient though; I can’t deny that!

$LULU 1yr later

I went into LULU last night (exactly 1yr since they announced buying The Mirror Co.) to pick up a few things.  I asked the Rep. how was the Mirror doing sales wise, and she told me that they’re doing about 30 sales on ave per month.

I was kind of shocked; I wasn’t expecting that.  Essentially one mirror per day.  This location is one of their upscale market location.  

Lulu has 491 stores.  Assuming their top 10% of stores are doing 30 units per month, that would put them around $32.5M on an annual basis, not including online.

That $500M acquisition was smart at the time, but now I like it even more.

Following up on my $VIEW post; I went for a nice walk last night that kind of indirectly revealed the lesson as to why the drop in VIEW pissed me off so much.

I currently live in Miami, but I’m in NYC to attend an engagement.  As I walked through the city, thinking about my day, I remembered why this city will always be my favorite place, no matter where I find myself in the world.

As much as I love the aesthetics where I live, I miss the culture (energy, hustle) of NYC, even though I haven’t lived/worked here for 12+ years.  Miami is nice, but it’s too laid back for someone like me who comes from the N.E., where most people are focused and grinding.

Which brings me to View.  SPAC attack aside, the lesson that I learned remembered was regardless of whether or not the product is great, you’re ultimately investing in Mgmt.  Of all of the SPACs that I’ve followed/invested in ( $OPEN $FUBO $SOFI $PRCH ) PRCH is the only one in which I have 100% confidence in mgmt (IPOE is #2).

$VIEW Days like this are tough.  I’m not going to sugarcoat it or spin some BS theory trying to rationalize what happened.

The truth is, even though I’m still holding the stock, the lack of demand to offset the ST manipulation does cause one to doubt their investment thesis.

As much as I believe in the company LT based on the DD, something here stinks!  The price has not been able to rise above the initial pre-merger price since the merger.  Sure the company keeps announcing new projects, but mgmt has been silent otherwise.

Long story short, I’m going to keep holding, but I’m pissed.  The only thing that I can do is to try and figure out the lesson here.

$PTON $FIT

I know that they are different types of businesses, and I’m bullish on PTON and still use my Fitbit, but the difference in valuation is startling.

They both have similar share counts, both have similar annual revenues (PTON is growing, but don’t forget at one point FIT was doing over $2B as well), both are losing the same amount on an annual basis, yet PTON is worth $19B & FIT is $1.9B ($2.1B after buyout).

By all measures FIT should’ve dominated the tech/fitness space.  Back in the day I truly believed that they would be the #1 health company of the future.

This is a tragic lesson of how, as the market leader, you can never rest on past wins.  Within the past 7 days I’ve seen ads for at least four other companies coming out of the woodwork to enter the PTON space (rowers, bikes, another mirror company, etc.).

I’m hoping PTON learned for FIT’s mistakes.

$PTON $WW $LULU $PLNT $HLF
(Spoiler alert: long post)

14% or 45M people in the US have a gym membership.  What would PTON be worth if it captured let’s say 20% of that market? 

Like most other growth/“disruption” companies, PTON is a classic example of  the difference between the trader mindset vs the investor mindset.

Traders get caught up in what a stock is doing based on “the chart”, & to a certain degree the fundamentals.

Investors also get caught up in the fundamentals, especially when the fundamentals don’t support a rich valuation, but the key differentiator is being able to look 3-5 years out, minimum, & bring non-quantitative elements into the analysis such as social trends, for example.

I’m a 3+yr investor for the most part, & can admit that I too got caught up in the rich valuation not being supported until I found myself contemplating canceling my gym membership (which also has Pelotons btw); that’s when I realized that in home, smart connected workouts is the future.

$VBIV I catch a lot of flack for posting long posts, but this is why I do it; to thoroughly document my thought process so that I can go back and review my analytical process on both my winners & losers.

The goal is to find a correlation between my significant winning trades, and apply those same levels of DD when researching future names.

This one was a trade that I wouldn’t normally have made being that a) it’s a bio, & b) it’s a penny stock; both of which I normally steer clear of, but I remember taking my time while researching this one, before I pulled the trigger.  That level of DD paid off; maybe there was a bit of luck involved, but either way, 489% ROI in less than 12 months, & wasn’t a pump & dump, as proven by the continued ascent, not bad.

This is the level of DD that I’m striving for on all of my trades/investments.

We know that today is going to suck.  A lot of names that everyone in their right mind knew was overvalued will be punished through the weekend and into next week.

The good; patient investors waiting for a pullback to a reasonable price, will be rewarded with a chance to establish a position at a fair cost basis once the pullback is over.

The bad; we won’t have a true sense of a fair cost basis until we’re through the Q2 earnings season.  This could be a well needed correction, or, depending on Q2 results and more importantly guidance, this could be the start of a multi-year slide towards a trough, at which point a fair cost basis won’t be known until the end of the next two earning seasons; Q3 minimum.

We shall see; it sucks either way.  Deploy capital cautiously; revisit value names to increase positions, establish positions in LT growth names after the smoke clears.

Use 2022 ITM LEAPs were possible to leverage cash (buy now pay later).

$PSTL

Based on FY2019/Q12020 results (finally had time to really dig into this one)

The good:
*Revenue growth; check

*Dividend growth; check (initial target is $1.20 per share)

*Mgmt aligned with shareholders; check (buying shares on the open market; CEO & CFO both elected to defer their bonus.  Employees also deferred a portion of the salary)

*Predictable and stable LT growth; check

*Niche; check

*Occupancy rate is 100% (obviously) & renewal rates are 98% 

The bad:
*SG&A jumped from 17 to 43% as a percentage of revenue (non-cash compensation is a major contributor).  This pressure on the bottom line will most likely continue until a certain Rev level is reached to offset it

*Acquisitions are growing nice.  PSTL owns 567 Post Offices.  23k privately owned POs, of which 16k are owned by individuals, which leaves a vast opportunity to increase their holdings, but acquisition cost can vary widely

*Debt will likely keep increasing to fund acquisitions 

*Extremely thinly traded

$AMZN I’m as much of a Peter F Drucker fan as the next guy, so I truly believe that the purpose of a business is to create and keep customers.  

This is why Bezos is brilliant.  Imagine how much the stock would’ve skyrocketed today if they reduced it to $3.5B and trickled down a buck per share to us humble shareholders in the form of a divi?  Now compare that $1 to how much the stock will appreciate per share over the next 3 years because of that reinvestment.

The best CEOs are truly masters of Capital Allocation.  It may not seem as if he is reinvesting to make more money, but he is reinvesting to keep workers safe and healthy, which will result in continued unparalleled customer service, which will ultimately lead to creating and keeping customers.

Even though I think the price is a little rich, it was the right call.  Hats off Bezos!

My in-person Series 65 training class scheduled for next week was just cancelled.  

Kaplan informed that all classes are cancelled until May at the earliest.  I get it, but I’m still pissed, but it got me to thinking after zooming out and thinking on the Macro level about what the impact of COVID will have if it escalates.

Looking at employment in industries that will be most affected if we head into a slowdown:

7.6M Construction workers
12.8M Manufacturing workers
15.7M Retail workers
5.7M Transportation workers

On average these are workers whose paycheck is a direct derivative of consumer behavior, meaning, their job security and paycheck has a direct correlation with people buying and spending.  So the economic threat becomes two fold; if everyday economic activity slows down, businesses take a hit, but so does a sizable portion of workers with loss wages; which leads to foreclosures, an accelerated slowdown in spending, etc.

$TSLA is probably the closest thing; folks buy the car and think “I want the truck too” which is crazy since it’s a $90K purchase.

Random thoughts: Charts aside, virus aside, when household brand names with good fundamentals start to breakdown in price, some heading towards >5yr lows with extremely low P/Es, see $M $CPRI, what does that tell us about the market, the economy and the potential risk waiting ahead for overvalued names?

Ex: I’ve been watching the price on $CCL What I find amazing is that the price is at Q3-2008 levels (it dropped from $39.35 on 1/1/2008 & bottomed at $19.56 on 1/1/2009; 50% decline whereas $QQQ dropped 35% over the same time period, but continued to lose another 13% through Q1 2019).

The similarities in price action is fascinating to a data nerd like myself; the breakdown in price action of household brand names happens prior to the breakdown in overvalued names, almost as if it were an early warning sign for the overall market; whereas one would think that it should be the opposite, tech first then household names.

$JBSS very interesting stock that I came across while doing some research lately on companies with significant family/founder holdings.

One of my tenants of LT investing is try to align a portion of your holdings with family run names with a history of well run, fiscally responsible companies with significant family wealth tied to the business.  The thesis of the tenant is that as the family manages the business to increase their wealth, you benefit (like the little fish that swim along bigger fish enjoying the flow of the current with minimum effort).

This is a very boring, non-fancy business with good fundamentals & a divi track record.  The 5yr chart is beautiful with 100% appreciation in value, and the inception to date chart (ITD) is even more gorgeous with a 540% gain over the past 25 years (+ a divi on top).

As I tweak my LT philosophy, I love coming across findings like this.  What more can you ask for; simple, steady, profitable growth with value returned to shareholders.

So I’ve been watching the market for the most part over the past 2 weeks; looking for extreme bargain plays, but also being cautious rather than hasty, and noticed $MGM today.

My immediate thought was wow, a world class brand almost trading at less than $20, this is a steal (22.54 currently)!

Just started listening to “100 Baggers” on $AMZN Audible by Christopher W Mayer.  It’s a very interesting examination of how to ignore the noise of daily headlines/price action on “trading”, and think about stocks from the LT perspective.

The book is a continuation of 100 to 1 by Thomas William Phelps, which essentially was a study of stocks, culled from the 1930s, that returned 100 to 1, and examines the similar attributes that each had, and how long it took.

As most who have participated in the markets for a while know, there is no exact science or rhyme or reason, but this book frames the data up rather nicely and, if nothing else, will offer a new perspective of what to look for when examining potential investments to hold for the long-term.

This may sound strange but $GRWG appears to have that potential.  If/when Rev reaches $100M+, it will have grown by 10,000% since Fiscal 2014.

There’s a good possibility they become significantly profitable in FY20, which could be a nice catalyst to the stock.  I also like that $MCD & so many others went plant based.  If the biggest food franchise in the world is doing plant based, then this is more than just a fad.

$TSLA has made me a believer (I’ve always been a believer in Musk, just not the stock’s valuation).  But after watching this insane run, it finally dawned on me that we no longer live in the old world of undervalued, growth at a reasonable price based on fundamentals, and that I may need to partially change my approach.

With that said, $BYND is making me a believer as well.  Recently, Cramer called BYND “a millennial stock”.  If memory serves me correctly, about 2-3 years ago Cramer said the same thing about TSLA.

BYND & TSLA share a lot of similar qualities.  

Qualitatively, they are both controversial names taking on a stagnant industry in which people have a strong opinion either way about the stock, but none are neutral.

Quantitatively, since FY14 every 2 years cumm TSLA Rev grew by 150%+

BYND seems to be doing one better.  In FY16 their Rev was $16M, FY17 $32M, FY18 $88M and in the first 9 months of FY19 their Rev was $192M.  That’s insane; but also relevant.

$PGNY made the decision to sell my call options on this one at a loss due to the recent volatility and pullback BUT, I bought the shares outright at $28.25

It might seem hasty to take a loss so early prior to them reporting ER, and it is, but here’s my logic.  I’ll take the loss on options if I can buy the shares outright at a price lower than I would’ve paid to exercise the calls.  Ex. I bought the Dec $25 calls for $12+ (also had the July $15s).  When I sold, I took a loss of roughly $300

By buying near $28, I eliminate the time decay risk, and set myself up for greater returns as I now own the shares so once this crosses $31, I’m break-even on that $300 loss and anything above that is more than I would’ve made in gains waiting for it to hit $37.

If it hits $37 by Dec (which it definitely should), I’d be up $900+ or more (assumes one call exercised for 100 shares), so the $300 loss on the calls is mute.  This is a simple example of managing risk.

$AMZN today should be very interesting.  If they pin this and don’t allow it to close above the ATH of $2,035, I don’t know what additional evidence is needed to prove that the market is controlled by deep pocket large capital funds, and the only weapon that regular retail investors such as myself have in our arsenal is good analysis and time.

ST trades puts anyone trading with less than $1M at a disadvantage, no matter how right you might be in determining where the stock is ultimately headed, especially with options trading.  You simply can’t get around the fact that big money can dictate ST action.  The best approach is to either invest for the LT, or if trading options, make the trade that is at least 6 months out or more.
